MainHeading.Title: Written Answers . - Environmental Impact of Arterial Drainage .

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for the Environment if he has any proposals to make grants available for the relandscaping of areas which have been subject to major arterial drainage works.

asked the Minister for the Environment if he has received any representations from individuals or organisations regarding the damage to the natural landscape which can be caused by major arterial drainage schemes.
asked the Minister for the Environment if he proposes to issue a policy statement on the connection between arterial drainage of our lakes and rivers and the tourism value of the natural environment.

asked the Minister for the Environment if he has in his Department a landscape specialist or landscape architect who is employed in a permanent and full-time capacity; and, if so, the level at which he or she is employed, and the range of responsibilities which they have.

asked the Minister for the Environment if he proposes to indicate guidelines to local authorities regarding the environmental impact of major arterial drainage schemes, particularly those connected with rivers and lakes.
asked the Minister for the Environment if he has seen recent reports about the environmental damage that is being caused to the landscape as a result of major arterial drainage schemes.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment (Mr. Barrett) Minister for the Environment (Mr. Barrett)
Speaker.P: : With the permission of the Ceann Comhairle I propose to take Questions Nos. 87 to 92 together.

I am aware that landscape damage resulting from arterial drainage schemes has been referred to in some recent press articles but I do not appear to have received any representations from individuals or organisations regarding such damage. For reasons which I shall indicate, I have no immediate proposals to issue either a policy statement on the connection between arterial drainage and tourism or guidelines for local authorities, nor have I proposals to make specific grants available for the relandscaping of areas which have been subject to major arterial drainage works.

I should like to point out to the Deputy that arterial drainage works are not subject to planning control nor, indeed, to any control which may be exercised by local authorities or by me. It is the Commissioners of Public Works who are charged with responsibility for execution of such works under the Arterial Drainage Act, 1945. The commissioners are empowered to prepare a drainage scheme whenever they are of opinion that the execution of arterial drainage works is expedient in respect of any catchment area for the purpose of preventing or substantially reducing flooding of lands in that area or of improving by drainage lands in the area.

MainHeading.P: Furthermore, confirmation of a drainage scheme is a function of the Minister for Finance. When the appropriate procedure has been followed and a scheme has been confirmed, the Commissioners are thereby empowered
—to construct, execute and complete the specified drainage works with such additions, omissions, variations and deviations as may be necessary,
—to enter on any land and there do such acts and things as may be necessary for or incidental to the works,
—to acquire compulsorily lands, easements, water rights and other rights proposed in the scheme to be so acquired,
—to interfere substantially with any land proposed in the scheme to be so interfered with,
—to restrict, terminate or otherwise interfere with any easement, fisheries, water rights or other rights proposed in the scheme to be compulsorily restricted, terminated or interfered with, and
—to divert, remove or otherwise interfere with any roads or bridges proposed in the scheme to be diverted, removed or interfered with.

The Act provides for exhibition of a drainage scheme when prepared by the Commissioners, for notice to be given to a variety of persons, and for any observations received to be considered before the scheme is confirmed. The council of a county in which lands will be affected are allowed three months to examine the scheme and submit observations. Any other local authority charged with the maintenance of any public road or bridge proposed to be diverted, removed or otherwise interfered with are allowed one month to submit observations. Given the nature of the scheme and the type of information which it provides, I think it will be readily understood that the local authorities would be expected to give special attention to such matters as roads, bridges, intakes for public water supplies and sewage outfalls or disposal works, not to mention the financial implications on transfer of the completed drainage works for maintenance in the future.

The Act also requires that various Ministers, including myself, should be consulted by the Commissioners when they have considered the observations received. In so far as my jurisdiction is concerned, it seems clear that the purpose of the consultation envisaged by the Act was mainly to obtain advice on matters raised by local authorities and, if possible, resolve any difficulties before the scheme was submitted to the Minister for Finance for confirmation. In any event, that has been the approach adopted when such matters were being dealt with in my Department. The commissioners have power to alter a scheme at that stage.

Since the Government have recently conferred on me a general responsibility to promote the protection and improvement of the environment, I now have a particular interest in the environmental impact of arterial drainage schemes and I have made arrangements to ensure that this aspect will, in so far as the particulars in the schemes allow, be considered whenever I am consulted. I do not have a landscape architect on the staff of my Department at present but advice of specialist staff which includes a landscape architect, is available to me.

I wish to make it clear, however, that the primary responsibility for environmental impact of arterial drainage schemes does not rest with me. The Government Statement on Ministerial responsibility for environmental matters laid down the following:

It will be the responsibility of each Minister to ensure that the environmental effects and implications of policies, programmes and projects undertaken by his Department, and by bodies for which he is the appropriate Minister, are fully considered before decisions are taken and that such decisions will take due account of environmental considerations, including national environmental policy.

Finally, I would like to point out to the Deputy that it would be unreasonable to expect that the type of works involved in arterial drainage schemes could be carried out without any adverse effects, and that there are considerations of cost involved also. The disadvantages—some of a temporary nature—must be balanced against the benefits.

From inquiries I have made, I am aware that a reappraisal has been made by the Commissioners of Public Works of the traditional method of disposal of spoil, that unsightly features are kept to a minimum and that particular attention will be given to avoidance of any unnecessary damage to scenery in sensitive areas. I am assured that any representations regarding special features such as trees, mills and weirs are considered sympathetically and there is no indiscriminate destruction of such features. It may be of interest to the Deputy to know that a whole series of hydro-metric investigations were carried out to see if a water wheel at Mantry could be retained and that proposals have been submitted to the owner for his consideration, that in the Boyne scheme, also, the commissioners were complimented by local organisations on their handling of works and spoil through the town of Trim, that in the Maigue scheme special steps have been taken to restore the river architecture through Adare Manor and that an internationally recognised landscape architect has been employed to ensure that all reasonable works are carried out to restore pre-drainage features.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M. Cosgrave Mr. M. Cosgrave
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for the Environment the relationship between his Department and water safety associations; and the amounts of grants made available to these bodies.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment (Mr. Barrett) Minister for the Environment (Mr. Barrett)
Speaker.P: : The only water safety body with which my Department have a direct relationship is the Irish Water Safety Association which was set up in 1971 by the then Minister for Local Government. The association operate generally under the aegis of the Department.

An annual grant is paid by my Department to the association and provision has been made this year for a grant of £32,000. Local authorities also make contributions to the association and to other bodies concerned with water safety.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M. Cosgrave Mr. M. Cosgrave
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for the Environment the steps he is taking to advise bathers this summer in relation to water safety.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment (Mr. Barrett) Minister for the Environment (Mr. Barrett)
Speaker.P: : The current water safety campaign was inaugurated by the Minister for State at a press conference on 1 June. The main objective of the campaign, which is being undertaken by my Department in conjuction with the Irish Water Safety Association, is to create an awareness of the need for bathers and others to take reasonable care while in or near the water. Life saving demonstrations and classes in swimming, life saving and resuscitation are among the activities being held throughout the country as part of the campaign, which is supported by suitable publicity containing advice for bathers.

I have also requested local authorities to review their water safety arrangements, including the erection of warning notices at danger spots and the provision at bathing areas of explanatory notices on the significance of flags used by lifeguards.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers . - Valuation Office Staff .

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Finance the duties that have now been allocated to the staff in the capital taxation section of the Valuation Office, who are engaged in wealth tax assessment; if any additional members of the staff have now been allocated by the Valuation Office to carry out upwards revisions of valuations of shops, business premises and offices throughout the country; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Finance (Mr. Colley) George Colley
Speaker.P: : The principal functions of the Valuation Office are (a) to revise, in accordance with the Valuation Acts, the valuations of such rateable hereditaments as are listed annually for that purpose by the various rating authorities, and (b) estimation, at the request of the Revenue Commissioners, for various property tax purposes of the capital value of interests in immovable property.

MainHeading.P: All valuer staff are liable to be engaged on either of these duties and are interchangeable in these areas. While particular blocks of staff are assigned to these duties, temporary transfer of staff from one duty to another is required on occasion to meet peak and pressure periods. Apart from adapting to such occasional needs, there has been no basic alteration in the amount of attention devoted to capital taxes work. It should be noted that the annual revision of valuations has to be completed and the results issued to the rating authorities by a statutory date, which this year will be 1 October next. Valuations dealt with on annual revision may be increased, reduced or left unaltered, each case being dealt with on its own merits. Since revisions of valuations are carried out at the initiative of the various rating authorities or of the individual ratepayer it would not be open to the Valuation Office to itself initiate a revision of valuations of shops, business premises and offices.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers . - Regional Development Fund .

Speaker.hpid: Mr. F. O'Brien Mr. F. O'Brien
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Finance if he will supply a list of the projects in Ireland which have received finance under the Regional Development Fund of the European Community, together with the amounts received by each of these projects in the various years in which the fund has existed.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Finance (Mr. Colley) George Colley
Speaker.P: : The European Regional Development Fund was established in March 1975 and the first projects were approved for fund assistance later that year. A total of 267 investment projects throughout the country and one study project have been approved for assistance to date. I propose, with the permission of the Ceann Comhairle, to circulate with the Official Report a list of these projects, broken down by category of project and the year of approval for fund aid.

MainHeading.P: In relation to the second part of the question, I should explain that it has not been the practice to give figures for fund aid for individual projects. Applications for fund assistance in respect of individual projects costing less than ten million units of account (£4.17 million) are, in accordance with article 7 of the fund regulation, submitted on a grouped basis for the country as a unit and the Commission determines a single aggregate aid figure for the grouped application. Accordingly, it is not feasible to specify the amount of fund aid approved or paid in respect of individual projects in this category which accounts for the vast bulk of the projects approved for fund aid in Ireland. Moreover, as the Deputy is probably aware, fund aid in respect of approved projects— whether above or below ten million units of account—is not used to “top up” the national aid already given to individual projects. Instead, it is applied at present to the financing of increases in certain services under the public capital programme and is expended as an integral part of that programme. However, the figures for the overall amounts of fund aid approved and received in the various years are included at the end of the list of projects which I am circulating.

asked the Minister for Industry, Commerce and Energy the action taken on foot of the recommendations of the Restrictive Practices Commission in their study of competition in the licensed drink trade; if formal discussions have taken place with any of the interests concerned; if the Government have considered the report and, in particular, if he is prepared to review the operation of the standstill order on drink prices, as part of an overall plan for greater competition in the trade.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Industry, Commerce and Energy (Mr. O'Malley) Desmond J. O'Malley
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Industry, Commerce and Energy (Mr. O'Malley)
Speaker.P: : The recommendations of the Restrictive Practices Commission in their study of competition in the licensed trade are being examined. Many of the recommendations are concerned with sensitive areas and need to be given very careful consideration before conclusions are reached on them. The order recognises any differentials in prices which may be due to the operation of competition within the trade. However, in any overall plan for greater competition in the trade arising from the examination of the report of the Restrictive Practices Commission or otherwise the operation of the standstill order would be borne in mind.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers . - Price Differences .

Speaker.hpid: Mr. F. O'Brien Mr. F. O'Brien
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Industry, Commerce and Energy why Northern Ireland prices are less, apart from tax reasons, than prices in the Republic for the identical product from the same supplier and the same factory; and if he will publish this information.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Industry, Commerce and Energy (Mr. O'Malley) Desmond J. O'Malley
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Industry, Commerce and Energy (Mr. O'Malley)
Speaker.P: : There can be a number of reasons, apart from tax, why the price of a product in Northern Ireland may be less than that for a product in this country. The difference in price may be due to such factors as the lower cost of distribution in Northern Ireland, differing green £ rates affecting the cost of agricultural produce, higher costs of production here, the operation of the special employment scheme in Northern Ireland, or the use there of price lists which are in operation in the UK and which do not take account of the transport costs from the UK and the smaller volume of sales in Northern Ireland.

MainHeading.P: In certain instances, where there was no obvious reason for the discrepancy between prices here and in Northern Ireland, the National Prices Commision carried out studies in an effort to determine the cause of the discrepancy. Summaries of these studies, which refer to distribution costs in Northern Ireland and the Republic, the prices of wheat and flour, grocery prices and motor vehicle prices, were published respectively in the November 1977, December 1977 January 1978, and April 1978 Reports of the National Prices Commission.

If the Deputy furnishes me with particulars of any product he had in mind when framing his question, I will arrange to have the matter of the prices here and in Northern Ireland for that product investigated.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for the Environment if, and when, he has received a request to meet the union representing employed taxi-drivers; and the action he is taking on the request.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment (Mr. Barrett) Minister for the Environment (Mr. Barrett)
Speaker.P: : I received a request to meet the taxi and hackney section of the National Association of Transport Employees union on 5 May. I also received similar requests from other taxi interests. MainHeading.Title: Written Answers . - County Donegal Group Water Scheme .

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for the Environment when money will be made available to allow the Lettermacaward, County Donegal group water scheme to proceed; if he is aware of the great need for piped water service in the district; and if he will avoid undue delay in the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment (Mr. Barrett) Minister for the Environment (Mr. Barrett)
Speaker.P: : Progress with the proposed group water supply scheme depends on the development of a source and the laying of trunk mains by Donegal County Council. My Department has asked the county council to submit additional documentation required in connection with consideration of contract documents for these works which will from Stage 1 of the proposed Lettermacaward regional water scheme. When this documentation is submitted, the council's proposals will receive early consideration in my Department.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Brady Mr. G. Brady
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for the Environment if, in view of the increasing number of small pleasure boats being sold in Ireland and the inherent danger associated with water sports, he will consider making the wearing of lifejackets and buoyancy aids obligatory.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment (Mr. Barrett) Minister for the Environment (Mr. Barrett)
Speaker.P: : In the case of pleasure craft let for hire or used for carrying passengers for hire, local authorities have power to attach conditions to the licences issued for such craft. I recently requested local authorities to consider attaching conditions relating to the provision of water safety equipment, to such licences.

There is no statutory power to deal with other pleasure craft. However, the Irish Water Safety Association, which operates under the aegis of my Department, avails of every opportunity to promote the use of suitable personal floatation devices of the type mentioned by the Deputy. In addition the association is examining, in consultation with the various water sport bodies, the need for further safety measures.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. F. O'Brien Mr. F. O'Brien
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Labour the average number of man-days lost due to absenteeism by each member of the workforce in the year for which the most recent information is available.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. F. O'Brien Mr. F. O'Brien
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Labour the average number of man-days lost due to absenteeism by each member of the workforce in (a) the Civil Service; (b) semi-State bodies; and (c) private sector employment, in the year for which the most recent information is available; and the steps he proposes to take to control the level of absenteeism from work.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Labour (Mr. G. Fitzgerald) Eugene (Gene) Fitzgerald
Speaker.P: : With the permission of the Ceann Comhairle, I propose to take Questions Nos. 158 and 159 together.
There is no obligation on employers to make returns of work-days lost through absenteeism. The information sought in the Questions is not therefore available from official sources.

I am aware, however, that various studies of absenteeism have been carried out in recent years. Reports on two of these studies have been published—“Absenteeism in Irish Industry”, by the Irish Productivity Centre, and “Absenteeism” by the Federated Union of Employers.

Evidence suggests that, apart from domestic pressures, a variety of factors can affect the level of absenteeism in a particular enterprise including dissatisfaction with wages or working conditions, the size of the organisation, the nature of the work processes, the nature of the consultation procedures and so on. I am aware also that in some enterprises means have been found to bring about a reduction in absenteeism.
In accordance with the Government's commitment to promote meaningful worker participation, I am at present engaged in examining ways and means of securing improvements in this general area.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers . - Leinster House Restaurant Staff .

Speaker.P: : A Cheann Comhairle, I finished my speech proper before Question Time but I would like to raise a matter now which I regard as of some importance.
: I will not argue a second time with the Deputy over a few minutes.

: I would like to ask you —I am sure in the name of every Deputy here—as the head of Leinster House and its administrative arrangements, to take a personal interest in regard to the situation of the Leinster House restaurant and bar staff. You probably know the situation which is confronting them, or which may confront them, and which was reported in the paper this morning. We will be all going now and not seeing each other until October and I would be glad if you, as Ceann Comhairle, would try to find some way of interesting yourself in what is going on and making sure that no hardship or injustice will result.
: The Chair will take note of what the Deputy has said.
